Column: 1273



    Let me start by setting the issue in some perspectives. Firstly, on the one hand, it has been said and acknowledged that there is a problem. For whatever reasons, there are Singaporeans who have left, are leaving or, at least, are thinking of leaving Singapore, and this has caused concern and has caused the Prime Minister to make certain remarks during his National Day Rally speech. Indeed, his remarks have generated a great deal of debate and some strong responses from Singaporeans, especially those who are living overseas. Some of these remarks or responses can be considered quite emotional and whether or not they are justified in their reaction is beside the point. What is important is to understand why they feel that way.

    Secondly, on the other hand, these few weeks have really witnessed quite a revolution in our country. And almost on a daily basis, we read about some new recommendations made by the Economic Review Committee as well as the Remaking Singapore Committee. And they cover just about everything and anything ranging from our economy to education, to laws and regulations as well as sports, and so on. And some of these recommendations are quite radical, recognising that today's world cannot be remodelled based on yesterday's memories.

    So it would be fair to say that it is not as if the Government is not doing anything. On the contrary, a great number of people, as has been confirmed, had been involved in trying to think of ways and means to improve the quality of life in Singapore. So as we talk about how to review thoroughly our programmes and policies, I do believe that process is well underway. Perhaps, there should be some focus, and this has been greatly debated upon, on this, what you call, sense of belonging of Singaporeans to Singapore and how to create the bonds within this great family about us.

    Maybe we should start by looking at mindsets and attitudes, I think, not only of the Government but indeed of

Column: 1274

Singaporeans, ourselves. We should re-examine our own attitudes towards Government, towards our country, and maybe start by not complaining so much. I think both sides, for sure, have to come together. Both sides have got to be part of the solution together.

    A sense of belonging, or a lack of it, has two aspects - the push factors as well as the pull factors. And, invariably, these factors always come into play as one considers or exits from a relationship, be it one's job, family, friends, social networks or country. One of the most major push factors must be this feeling of alienation. There is no doubt about it that we are a hard-driving and yet a high-achieving nation. There is nothing wrong with it. The strategy that has helped to produce this state is correct and should be continued. But this strategy, this process, also produces on the one hand the high achievers whom we want because they are the drivers and, on the other hand, people or groups who might just feel marginalised, disenfranchised or disenchanted, as had been described.

    So, really, our challenge is to develop policies and programmes which will accommodate this diverse range of expectations and aspirations, ranging from high rewards, philosophical expressions as well as just mere basic needs. We, therefore, need to create an environment and strive to create even a better environment which does not label people and which makes everybody feel needed and welcomed. That way, we avoid that feeling of alienation.

    That is of course the most ideal situation to achieve and, needless to say, we must always try to achieve it. Everyone counts and everyone matters, whatever their abilities and disabilities, whatever they have done or not have done. We must welcome, as done, all members of our family, because they belong to our family. We should also embrace those who, for whatever reasons, have left Singapore, and we must maintain good relationships and good ties with them because we are a small country. This way, we enlarge our virtual family. And, it is an asset.

Column: 1275



    There are good reasons why Singaporeans choose sometimes to leave the country - because of personal reasons, opportunities or survival, like in the business world. Businesses may take flight to low-cost regimes in order to stay competitive. This way, we should applaud and encourage them, because they have moved on, seeking that proverbial cheese, so to speak. This is not to say that we shall quit and seek cheese elsewhere because we have got plenty of cheese in Singapore and we know that the Government is constantly trying to increase that cheese supply. What I am just trying to say is that we should embrace all Singaporeans who have left us temporarily or permanently, and include them in this family of ours. And I would add that we should also include new members or foreign talent, because if they want to, are willing to and are able to improve our lives, why not? Why should we criticise them? We should welcome them because they are part of this global intellectual capital - this is 3G - which is so mobile, they go to where they are wanted, they stay where they are well treated and valued.

    This brings me to my recent visit to the US. I am reminded of how patriotic that country is. The Americans are so proud of themselves. They loudly proclaim they are Americans, whatever their country of origin might be. The minute they receive their green cards, they announce that they are Americans. Why is this so? We all know that America is a very rich and prosperous country. It is lauded as the land of opportunity. It is proclaimed as the champion of human rights as well as democracy. But so is Singapore. Singapore is a highly successful country, and there are a good number of reasons why we should also be proud and loudly proclaim ourselves as Singaporeans.

    But I think the Americans have a great symbol of their country which they can relate to, and this is their flag. Americans proudly display their flag on every occasion, not only on national occasions, not only during community gatherings, but also during family as well as business gatherings. Many Americans fly their flag throughout the year in their homes and

Column: 1276

their offices, not only on Independence Day. And they also wear their flag literally - on hats, clothes, T-shirts, mini-skirts, hot pants, mugs and so on. It is not disrespectful at all. In fact, the flag is a strong symbol of freedom, democracy, pride in their country, as well as loyalty to the country.

    Indeed, the strength of a country, or creed, lives very much in the true sense of loyalty it can arouse in the hearts of its people. And, therefore, the value of the flag is so powerful in uniting a country and its people, making them believe in the country and what it stands for, I think we should develop a great sense of loyalty for our country. In that way, we promote that sense of belonging to our country as well.

    But this sense of loyalty or a sense of belonging must also be founded in the value of the family, and this has been articulated by a lot of hon. Members here because, however the world changes, the power of the family remains in shaping and nurturing the citizens of tomorrow. It is within this family relationship that values as diverse as love, responsibility, communication and respect for the authority gets forged. It is within the family that we learn about how to live to the fullest of our potential, how to do the right things and do things right as well.

    So we can spend more time and more efforts in developing the family and developing policies and programmes which are much more pro-family. Already, we have a number of factors against us - the smallness of our family unit, the growing number of singles and childless couples. So I think it is worth our while to continue to really put in all our efforts in making and developing pro-family policies.

    There are also quite a few lessons which can be learnt - or I learned it - from Rudy Guiliani, who is the ex-Mayor of New York City. He was the keynote speaker at a recent event which I attended, and he was talking about Managing a Crisis. And it was not just about the September 11 crisis. He was talking about the difficulties he faced when he first

Column: 1277

became the Mayor of New York and how difficult it was for him to galvanise New Yorkers together. So he carried out a survey and was dismayed to find that 64% of New Yorkers would rather quit New York, if given the chance. That is a very high percentage. New York is one of the most successful cities in the world in one of the most successful countries in the world. Yet, they too have their fair share of potential quitters. So, we are not in this alone.

    Mr Guiliani changed that to a large extent. What he did was to establish the reasons as to why New Yorkers were unhappy. Not surprisingly, one of the main reasons is the high rate of crime in New York. Just imagine, there is an official list of tips on "How not to be a victim of crime" in New York! One of it is not to talk to strangers, and the other is not to have eye contact with anyone. This is much worse than our bo-chap policy; it is bo-chap policy with fear, ie, walk around with your eyes closed! What Mr Guiliani did after identifying the problems was really addressing the problems with great vigour. He developed a strategy, communicated the strategy, fought the battles with great focus and commitment and, as he said, with a great deal of optimism. That way, he succeeded in achieving what was thought to be impossible.

    I think we, too, can start by looking at the reasons why Singaporeans are unhappy, and much of it has already been articulated. I say it again: we are a country with a low rate of crime. We are a city which is clean, safe, efficient as well as affluent. We have great food. People are telling us that we are fun and an enjoyable place to live in, and yet Singaporeans are unhappy. Why is this so? A lot of reasons have already been articulated by many hon. Members here, but I would like to dwell on three. Is it due to our inherent complaining nature, to start with? Or is it due to what the Prime Minister said, that we are a bo-chap, couldn't-care-less society? Or are we a kiasu society as well?

Column: 1278



    All these attitudes are not desirable and, indeed, they should be reversed. They should be replaced by values which will make us a much happier society. So, instead of being kiasu, I think we too should have a good dose of optimism, because it is in optimism that we see solutions, and pessimism simply obscures solutions, even as they stare us in our faces. I think we should also stop complaining and become a much more self-reliant society. That way, we take greater pride in our work. That way, we become much more entrepreneurial as well. As for bo-chap, I think that is terrible. We must chap. We must care. That way, we will have a more caring and more gracious society, not only for ourselves but for everybody else as well, because democracy is not just about rights, it is also about respect and responsibility for others.

    On that note, I would like to conclude by saying that I do believe that as we remake Singapore, these values - of inclusiveness, loyalty, family, responsibility and optimism - get woven into our policies and programmes.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mdm Deputy Speaker, may I set the debate in context by sketching out the major issues which are behind this debate about stayers and quitters.

    We are really talking about two distinct but related issues here. One, rooting Singaporeans emotionally to Singapore, in other words, developing a national identity, patriotism, a sense of belonging, a sense of pride in being a Singaporean. Two, getting Singaporeans to stay physically in Singapore rather than emigrating, working or living overseas. The first is a crucial long-term issue; the second is an important medium-term one.

    Rooting citizens is a critical but very difficult task for many new countries, especially those which have not been born as nations to start off with. A Professor of Government in Harvard, Rupert Emerson,

Column: 1279

gave a definition of a nation which is relevant to this, and I quote him:

    "A single people, traditionally fixed on a well-defined territory, speaking the same language and preferably a language all its own, possessing a distinctive culture, and shaped to a common mould by many generations of shared historical experience."

    So, there are many ingredients - a single people, well-defined territory, same language and preferably a language of its own, possessing a distinctive culture, and shaped to a common mould by many generations of shared historical experience. This definition by Prof. Rupert Emerson and was quoted by Prof. Robert Tilman from the University of North Carolina who wrote a book about "South East Asia and the Enemy Beyond" which was published in 1987. Prof. Tilman also pointed out that by this definition, Thailand is the only country in South East Asia which is a nation, and even then, only if the Thai Muslims in the South are excluded.

    All new countries which are not born nations have this problem. Myanmar, with its two dozen different tribes; Indonesia, with its many different races and languages, spread over 10,000 or more islands; Malaysia, with Malays, Indians, Chinese and others. If we look beyond South East Asia, India has the same issue of identity, because India was never one country before the Raj. And their separate local identities which had to be blended together and harmonised as one Indian identity. On top of which, they had their religious divide between the Hindus and the Muslims, because India has a large Islamic minority - 100 million.

    Or take Pakistan. All Muslims, but West Pakistan was different from East Pakistan. The Punjabis, Sindhis and others in West Pakistan are different from the Bengalis in the East, and there was a civil war after which Bangladesh was born, and Pakistan was split into two. So many countries have this problem, and Singapore too. If you examine the definition, we did not get born as a nation either.

    Therefore, how do you root people to the country? That is the challenge. What

Column: 1280

has this Government done to do that? We have built a meritocratic, multi-racial society. We have given every citizen a stake in Singapore. Through home ownership, through HDB, 90% of Singaporeans now own their homes. We have generated economic growth and prosperity, and given every Singaporean a share in Singapore's success. We emphasise education in national schools, to inculcate values, to imbue students with knowledge of their mother tongue and also to equip them with skills so that they can make a living for themselves. Therefore, today Singapore is a success, and we have a much stronger sense of nationhood today than we did in 1965. So when Mr Low Thia Khiang made a rousing speech in Chinese saying that it is all the Government's fault, it sounds good but it is not so.

There was no issue of Singaporeans leaving in the previous generation. The question never arose because for that generation, which country to belong to was not a matter of choice. Either they were born in Singapore or they had come here out of economic necessity. Many of them did not speak English and could not easily uproot themselves and their families and go off to some other country. And even if they could have gone, they would have felt out of place, uncomfortable and yearning for something more like home.

    But today, it is different. Today, Singa-poreans have many opportunities. There is globalisation. Other economies have opened up. There is a global market for talent. Many countries now emphasise talent and open their doors to welcome people who have skills and talent. Because we have given them education, because Singaporeans speak English, because Singaporeans are prosperous, so if they want to move, many Singaporeans will be welcomed in many places. So there is a choice.

    Our pattern of emigration has changed. In the 70s and 80s, we used to worry about people who would leave Singapore

Column: 1281

as mature adults in their 30s and 40s. They have grown up, they have started working, they have a family and they have bought a house. Now, they are thinking of selling their house, cashing out, bringing their families, and moving away to Canada or somewhere.

It is so exciting and they put off coming back till another time. It is a real problem. We had a group of overseas Singaporeans who came to brief the Economic Review Committee a few months ago from Hong Kong, Stanford in San Francisco, and Harvard and MIT in Boston.     We acknowledge that not all Singaporeans will stay here in a globalised world. Just as we welcome foreigners to come to Singapore, so too other countries invite Singaporeans, and some will go. Apart from that, there would be reasons why Singaporeans need to go overseas to work, to learn, to be posted, to do a job. In fact, I would encourage Singaporeans who have this opportunity to go abroad, to take it up, to learn about the world, expand your horizons. But, at the same time, I hope that when Singaporeans are overseas, they will maintain their links back home and after spending their time overseas, and after some time, come back to Singapore.

Column: 1282

fang, xin huai zu guo". If everybody is north, east, south and west of Singapore and there is nobody in the centre, then the centre is going to have a problem, which is like Ireland which, for centuries, sent millions of people overseas to the English-speaking world - America, Britain, Australia, New Zealand, Canada.     The PRC is in a different position. They have 1.2 billion people, many, many talented ones, and they have been sending students overseas in big numbers - 20,000 a year, and an estimated 380,000 since they opened up about 20 years ago. Column: 1283

Of course, while we keep in touch with those who are overseas, we must look after those who have not left.

The Government will consider all of them, and in wherever they are workable and practical. Mr Hawazi and Dr Ng Eng Hen have responded on the education issues, on how we have a good system, but we can improve it. And particularly, I think we have to deal with the specific difficulties which caused this to be one of the push factors, which caused some Singaporeans to leave the country. We also have to think about our overall approach to engaging citizens and involving those who want to be part of the national debate. For that, we have the Remaking Singapore Committee which Dr Vivian Balakrishnan has been chairing and which he told you about.

    We have to engage the energies of our citizens. Singaporeans say they are not quite satisfied because they do not have enough say in what goes on in Singapore. I think we can create more say but, most important of all, we will have to be realistic about it. Singaporeans can have more say here in Singapore than they can have anywhere else. If you go to China and you want to change the system, it will take you several generations, and your great-grandson may succeed. If you go to America and you want to change the system, it is not so easy. It is a very complicated and large society. But in Singapore, if you have an idea, a dream, something which you want to achieve, you can make a difference. It is 3 million people. However modest your intentions, you cannot hide your light under a bushel,

Column: 1284

it will be seen and if it makes sense, it will be taken up and implemented. So in Singapore, we can do that.

    One idea which we have developed, arising out of the Economic Review Committee's experience with the students and the Singaporeans overseas, is to set up what we would like to call the "Majulah Connection". Our exercise with the students in America and Hong Kong involved, I suppose, a few dozen enthusiastic Singaporeans working overseas, activating their friends and colleagues, meeting late at night, discussing over the Internet.
